images.alt:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    PowerShell Pro Tools Logo
.DESCRIPTION
    An attempt at a PowerShell Pro Tools Logo, written in Turtle PowerShell
.NOTES
    Must be running chrome or chromium to save to PNG.
.LINK
    https://bsky.app/profile/adamrdriscoll.com/post/3m5z3ewuwrk2x
#>
param(
# The thickness of the chevron
[double]
$thickness = 42,

# The length of each side
[double]
$SideLength = 420,

# The distance between each chevron
[double]
$JumpDistance = 1kb,

# The number of repetitions.
# Each repetition is a base multiplier, making the image grow as we scale.
[ValidateRange(1,16)]
[int]
$RepeatCount = 3
)


turtle fill '#4488ff' @(
    foreach ($n in 1..$RepeatCount) {
        'forward',($n * $thickness)
        
        'rotate',-45

        'forward',($n * $SideLength)
        
        'rotate',-90
        
        'forward',($n * $SideLength)
        
        'rotate',135
        
        'forward', ($n * $thickness * -1)

        'rotate', 45
        
        'forward',($n * $SideLength)

        'rotate', 90

        'forward',($n * $SideLength)

        'rotate', 225

        'jump', $jumpDistance
    }
) stroke '#224488' save ./PowerShellProTools.svg save ./PowerShellProTools.png

record.text:
How's this for a first try?

And, I absolutely love adding these bonus points:

#PowerShell Source code in the alt text!

#Turtle #TurtlePower

Bonus points:  there are parameters so you can play around.

Have fun!
